author: Simon Meechan
title: How Brexit could hit you in the pocket with iPhone and iPad apps set to increase by 25%
text:
News How Brexit could hit you in the pocket with iPhone and iPad apps set to increase by 25% The tech giants have already increased computer prices by 20% and now a £0.79 app will cost £0.99 Share The App Store on an Apple iPhone 6s, as Apple is to raise the price of apps in the UK by up to 25% following the fall in value of the pound (Photo: PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
British Apple customers will be charged 25% more for iPhone and iPad apps due the sharp fall in the pound’s value after Britain voted to leave the European Union. 
Apple is rolling out the changes over the next week. They mean an app that costs $0.99 in the USA, which Apple charges £0.79 for in the UK, will soon cost £0.99. Act now if you want to snap up apps for £0.79. 
The American tech giant announced the price hike in an email to its app developers. 
The message, sent on Tuesday, states: “When foreign exchange rates or taxation changes, we sometimes need to update prices on the App Store”. What has Brexit got to do with it? Prime Minister Theresa May speaking at Lancaster House in London where she outlined her plans for Brexit 
Since Britain voted to leave the European Union on June 23 , the pound has fallen by 18.5% against the US dollar. 
Apple is based in America, so it raises prices in the UK to make up for the income it loses when the pound drops in value. Will computers, tablets and phones get more expensive? 
Apple has already increased prices on laptops and computers by up to 20%. The Mac Pro - a model which has not been updated since 2013 - has had its price bumped up by £500, from £2,499 to £2,999. 
A 13-inch MacBook Air, which is Apple’s cheapest laptop, now costs £949, up from £849. 
The Californian company hasn’t moved to increase the price of iPhones yet. Read More 
“Price tiers on the App Store are set internationally on the basis of several factors, including currency exchange rates, business practices, taxes, and the cost of doing business,” the company said in a statement. 
“These factors vary from region to region and over time.” Is it just Britain that is paying more? 
No, Turkey’s currency has dropped in value so Apple has raised prices there too.
